articles.title: Monitor your competitorâ€™s website performance using Monika
articles.dc:creator: Denny Pradipta
articles.content:encoded:
Letâ€™s say you have created a great website. You are competing in a red ocean where there are so many players in the existing market space. Within you, there is a big urge to beat the competition, you want your website to be the best in theÂ market.

You want to know if your website is more reliable than the others. Maybe other websites are slower, or maybe prone to service outages. You want proof that â€œWebsite X is slower than us when it comes to speedâ€ or â€œWebsite Y is unreliableâ€.

This article will help you to monitor your competitors using Monika with a single configuration file. So, without furtherÂ ado:

Monitor your competitors withÂ Monika

GitHub - hyperjumptech/monika: Monika is a command line application to monitor every part of your web app using a simple YAML configuration file. Get alert not only when your site is down but also when it's slow.

Monika is an open-source and free synthetic monitoring command-line application. Monika stands for â€œMonitoring Berkalaâ€, which means â€œperiodic monitoringâ€ in the Indonesian language. With Monika, you can add as many websites or endpoints as you want to monitor. You can monitor several conditions such as service outages or slow services.

You can configure Monika to send notifications of the incidents on your services through your favorite communication tools like SMTP mail, WhatsApp (itâ€™s free!), Microsoft Teams, Slack, and many more. There are 18 notification channels to this day that have been integrated intoÂ Monika.

To install Monika, you can choose whether you want to use Node Package Manager (NPM), download binaries from the Monika release page, package managers such as Homebrew or Snapcraft, or a DockerÂ image.

To run Monika in your system, you need to create a Monika configuration. Monika uses a YAML file to define all the settings and configurations. You can find a sample configuration file in the repository called monika.example.yml or create your own at the Monika Config Generator website.

Monitoring your competitors

Letâ€™s imagine that we are building an e-Commerce and we want to compare our website performance with other e-Commerces. We could use Indonesian big e-Commerces as our competitors:

Now that we have our competitors ready, itâ€™s time to create a Monika configuration.

Let me explain a little bit about this configuration:

  • Monika will use the Desktop notifications, but you can change it to your preferences.
  • Monika will probe four websites: tokopedia.com, shopee.co.id, bukalapak.com, and lazada.co.id
  • Each website will be probed in parallel, meaning that if one website is having an incident, the other websites will continue to beÂ probed.
  • Each website has a ten seconds interval and a five times incident/recovery threshold. Meaning each website will be monitored every ten seconds and Monika will notify you if there are five times consecutive incidents/recoveries.
  • Each website will alert you if the status code is not 200 or the response time is longer than two secondsÂ (2000ms)

Once the configuration is ready, itâ€™s time to run the configuration by running monika -c in your terminal.

You can also use a remote Monika configuration, just by running monika -c in your terminal.

Once there are alerts, you will be notified through your configured notifications channel. Congratulations! Now you can monitor your competitors' performance!

Closing

Monitoring your competitorâ€™s website performance is important so that by monitoring them, you can identify where they went wrong, and you will do everything to avoid their mistakes, and do everything right. The faster your website, the more likely it is that users will remain on the page and continue to browse yourÂ website.

If youâ€™re having a problem with using Monika, donâ€™t hesitate to create an issue on Monikaâ€™s Github Issue Page. If you like this article, donâ€™t forget to clap and share this article with yourÂ friends!

Thatâ€™s it for today, see you nextÂ time!

articles.title: Upgrade Cypress to Version 10
articles.dc:creator: Raosan Lillahi
articles.content:encoded:
Even though version 10 is a major version upgrade for cypress, turns out itâ€™s very simple and straightforward to do. You can read the complete explanation from the official documentation here. But if what you need is a step-by-step guide, then hopÂ in.

Disclaimer: I upgrade from version 8.7.0 but it should work too if you are from versionÂ 9.x.x

Upgrade theÂ package

First, we need to install the latestÂ cypress

npm install -D cypress@latest

Automatic Migration

Now you just need to complete 3 easy stepsÂ click.

Open the migration helperÂ GUI

npx cypress open

You will see the GUI and a video to watch. Then click the button: Continue to CypressÂ 10.

1. Rename existingÂ specs

In this step, all files in the integration folder will be moved to the e2e folder. Simply click the â€œRename these specs for meâ€Â button.

2. Rename cypress supportÂ file

Next, the migration tool will let you rename the Cypress support file. Click the â€œRename the support file for meâ€ button toÂ execute.

3. Migrate new cypress configÂ file

In the last step, the migration tool will move the existing Cypress config to a new file called â€œcypress.config.jsâ€. Click the â€œMigrate the configuration for meâ€ button to continue.

Finally, the screen below will appear if all went well. Click the â€œE2E Testingâ€ to go to your cypress testÂ specs.

â€œYay, you have done it if you make it tillÂ hereâ€

Changes from previousÂ version:

  • You can not run all specs in one click. Just 1 spec perÂ click.
  • The experimental â€œCypress Studioâ€ has beenÂ removed.
  • You need to add --browser and --e2e to go to specs list directly, for example, â€‹cypress open --browser chromeÂ --e2eâ€‹.

Code Coverage

If you use Code Coverage, you need to do an additional step because the Cypress Code Coverage plugin will need to be updated to version >= 3.10 to work with Cypress 10. Using a previous version will result in an error when tests are run with code coverageÂ enabled.

After upgrading the cypress-code-coverage, you might need to move the config like what IÂ did:

  • delete the cypress/plugins/index.ts file:
  • add the library-importing statement require('cypress/code-coverage/task')(on, config) inside e2e > setupNodeEvents

Now for theÂ twist

If you have done all that and can run all your spec tests, then you did well ğŸ‘. But for the user of TypeScript like myself, there is a twist that awaits you in the end. Especially if you also use jest as your component testing library, you will get many type errors about jest assertion and make you unable to build the app. Oh,Â sh*t.

Luckily, the answer is on Stackoverflow (like always) ğŸ˜. Just need to add a file and boom. All isÂ well.

In conclusion, major-upgrading 3rd party library is not as scary as it sounds. All you need is a calm mind, to read documentation, and to do the migration steps. Hope it will helpÂ you.

Additional note: Even though there is a component test in cypress version 10, we havenâ€™t used it because using jest is enough forÂ now.

articles.title: Monika 1.10.0 is out! Autocomplete, Sitemap, Chaining Requests, and More
articles.dc:creator: Denny Pradipta
articles.content:encoded:
Monika 1.10.0 is out! Autocomplete, Sitemap, Improved Chaining Requests, andÂ more

We are very excited to present you Monika v1.10.0, featuring:

  • Chaining Request using Response Body: Use previous requestsâ€™ response body in anotherÂ request
  • Autocomplete on Visual Studio Code: Using Visual Studio Code, you can now create Monika configuration using autocomplete
  • Run Monika using Sitemap: Run Monika without having to create a new configuration by using sitemapÂ files
  • Bug fixes: No further explanations areÂ needed.

Chaining Request using ResponseÂ Body

Previously, Monika users could only use previous requestsâ€™ responses in the subsequent requestâ€™s URL and Headers. Weâ€™ve got some feedback from a user on our GitHub Discussion page to be able to use previous requestsâ€™ responses in the request body, not only URL andÂ headers.

We have covered it in the articleÂ below:

Use Previous Requestsâ€™ Response as Request Body in Monika

Autocomplete on Visual StudioÂ Code

Monika Config Generator is pretty helpful for creating Monika configurations. But sometimes opening the website may become a hassle because you need to open your browser, navigate, and proceed through the long wizard if you have so many probes toÂ monitor.

Using Visual Studio Code with one extension, you can create Monika configurations using autocomplete feature. We have covered it in the articleÂ below:

Creating Monika Configuration from Scratch using Autocomplete in Visual Studio Code

Run Monika usingÂ Sitemap

Having a sitemap is not necessary, but it could speed up search engines to find and index new websites or updated webÂ pages.

In this version of Monika, you can run Monika with your sitemap or create a Monika configuration based on your sitemap. We have covered it in the articleÂ below:

Use your Website Sitemap as a Monika Configuration

Bug Fixes

We received some reports that if you are probing many probes, it may result in your probe timed out while doing so. After troubleshooting the problem (thanks to Nico Prananta), the problem was because of the following redirects mechanism inside Axios. We have added a flag called --folow-redirects for you to use so that you can control how many redirects you want toÂ follow.

Next, we have improved how Monika probes the endpoint by adding a simple flag called --max-start-delay for you to use so that Monika will start probing the probes at a slightly different time but still within the specified max start delay, meaning that if you have dozens of probes it will not begin altogether.

Also, we fixed the TCP probing mechanism so it will work thisÂ time.

Weâ€™re human, after all. Even Miley Cyrus says, â€œEverybody makes mistakesâ€. So if you happen to find any bugs when using Monika, do not hesitate to report them on our Github issuesÂ page.

Closing

Those are the highlights in this version. For more details about this release, consider checking out our Github release page to see more about thisÂ version.

If you have suggestions, feedback, feature requests, or willingness to contribute to Monika, donâ€™t hesitate to open a new issue or further discussion on our Github repository page.

If you like this article donâ€™t forget to clap and share this with your friends. If you think we miss something, drop your commentsÂ below.

Thatâ€™s it for today, see you in the nextÂ article!

articles.title: Use your Website Sitemap as a Monika Configuration
articles.dc:creator: Denny Pradipta
articles.content:encoded:
Taken from the Google website, a sitemap is a file where you provide information about the pages, videos, and other files on your site, and the relationships between them. Search engines read this file to crawl your site more efficiently.

Did you know Monika can use or generate a Monika configuration based on your existing websiteâ€™s sitemap? In case you didnâ€™t know, this feature has been released from MonikaÂ v.1.9.2.

This article will show you how to use or generate a Monika configuration based on your existing websiteâ€™s sitemap. So, without furtherÂ ado:

GitHub - hyperjumptech/monika: Monika is a command line application to monitor every part of your web app using a simple YAML configuration file. Get alert not only when your site is down but also when it's slow.

Monika is an open-source and free synthetic monitoring command-line application. Monika stands for â€œMonitoring Berkalaâ€, which means â€œperiodic monitoringâ€ in the Indonesian language.

With Monika, you can add as many websites as you want to monitor. You can monitor several conditions such as service outages or slow services. Also, you can configure Monika to send notifications of the incidents on your services through your favorite communication tools like SMTP mail, WhatsApp (itâ€™s free!), Microsoft Teams, Slack, and manyÂ more.

There are many ways to install Monika, from Node Package Manager (NPM), downloading binaries from the Monika release page, to package managers such as Homebrew or Snapcraft.

To run Monika with your sitemap, make sure that you have a sitemap.xml file available. If you donâ€™t have any sitemap yet, you can simply use a sitemap generator such as https://www.xml-sitemaps.com.

As an example, letâ€™s use the Monika landing page sitemap which can be found at https://monika.hyperjump.tech/sitemap.xml.

Save the sitemap.xml file to your local computer. Then, go to your terminal and run the command monika --sitemap to run Monika with theÂ sitemap.

Pretty cool right? But as you can see, if we directly run Monika with the sitemap file, you may notice that there are warnings about no alerts configuration defined. If you are comfortable with the predefined alerts, you may carry on. But if you want to add more alerts, you can generate a Monika configuration based on your sitemap by running monika --create-config --sitemap

Donâ€™t forget that you can use a remote sitemap.xml without having to save the sitemap file to your local just by changing the to any working link such as https://monika.hyperjump.tech/sitemap.xml.

Bear in mind that creating a Monika configuration based on the remote XML does not work at theÂ moment.

Congratulations, you can now monitor all the pages in your website usingÂ Monika!

Closing

A sitemap tells search engines which pages and files you think are important to your site and also provides valuable information about these files. If you already have a sitemap, then itâ€™s easier for you to useÂ Monika.

This article will tell you how to create Monika configurations from scratch, using only Visual Studio Code and a VS Code extension. So, Without furtherÂ ado:

Preparation

Letâ€™s start with installing Visual Studio Code if you havenâ€™t installed it on your computer yet. Head over to https://code.visualstudio.com/ and download the installation file according to your operating system.

After you installed Visual Studio Code, head to the Extension menu, and search for an extension called YAML created by Red Hat. Install the extension right away in order to enable the Monika configuration autocompletion.

Once youâ€™re done, create a file called monika.yml and try to type â€œnotificâ€. It will show you an explanation of the â€œnotificationsâ€ key.

Then proceed to type â€œnotifications:â€ all the way and press enter to break the line. You will see a warning that the â€œnotificationsâ€ key type should be anÂ array

Now some of you may think, â€œwhat if I donâ€™t know what to type in a blank file?â€. You can simply press CTRL+Space to show available options.

Also, it includes auto-complete when you select an option. For example, press CTRL+Space and select probes. It will automatically set a probe with an empty ID, ten seconds interval, and 5 times incidents/recoveries threshold.

If you have used Monika, you may notice that some keys are not there yet such as the URL and the Method. Below the id key, with the same indent, try to press CTRL+Space again and you will see all available keys inside a probeÂ object.

Now you can create your own Monika configuration using the methods above. For now, letâ€™s try to create a Monika configuration based on the pointsÂ below:

  • I want to use the Desktop notification channel
  • I want to create a single probe with the name â€œGoogleâ€, with any ID, has ten seconds interval, 10 times incidents/recoveries threshold
  • Inside the probe â€œGoogleâ€, I want to have a request that will hit https://www.google.com with the methodÂ GET

Try to do it yourself first and see if you can create the configuration from the points above similar to the configuration below:

If the configuration is similar to the one you created, then congratulations! All thatâ€™s left to do is to run it usingÂ Monika

Setup DingTalkÂ Robot

Setting up DingTalk could be very difficult if you canâ€™t read Chinese. So, we will guide you on how to do it with pictures so that you can understand it more straightforwardly.

First, you need to open https://open.dingtalk.com/document/group/assign-a-webhook-url-to-an-internal-chatbot to access the documentation. Then, you need to click the highlighted URLÂ below:

Assuming you already have a DingTalk account, you will be redirected to the page in the image below. If you havenâ€™t, you will be redirected to create anÂ account.

After that, go to the second menu on the navbar, and select the first sub-menu likeÂ so:

You will be redirected to another page. Select the last menu on the sidebar, and click the blue button to create aÂ robot.

After that, you will be prompted to fill out a form to create a robot. Fill out the form with the application name, description, and icon. Once thatâ€™s done, click the blue buttonÂ again.

If the bot has been successfully created, it should redirect you to the robot detailsÂ page.

But your newly created robot has not been activated yet, so letâ€™s activate the robot by selecting the last menu on the sidebar, then select the first sub-menu of it, and click the right blue button. Once thatâ€™s done, the red indicator should turnÂ green.

Use DingTalk Robot in the DesktopÂ App

Then, click the group and open the settings inside the group and click the Group Assistant menu.

From there, you can add your previously created robot. Click the robot name you have justÂ created.

A popup will appear showing your robot data. Scroll down to the webhook URL and copy the webhook URL to another place. Then, copy only the access token in the webhook URL. The access token format should be likeÂ this:

https://oapi.dingtalk.com/robot/send?access_token=

Save it to somewhere safe as we are going to need itÂ later.

Additionally, you can secure your robot by allowing keywords. Scroll down to Security Settings and check the Custom Keywords checkbox. From there, you can define the keywords allowlist yourself.

We are finally done with the DingTalk setup, all thatâ€™s left is to set up Monika with the DingTalk webhookÂ URL.
